snippet: Law enforcement officials and some Somali leaders said the new programs were a way to stop extremism long before an arrest became necessary.
abstract: Announcement from federal prosecutors that Minneapolis area will receive about $1 million to underwrite programs aimed at preventing radicalization of young Somali-Americans by extremist Islamic groups stirs skepticism and wariness throughout region's large Somali population; announcement comes hours after Minneapolis teenager admitted in court he had tried to flee city to join Islamic State.

byline.original: By CHRISTINA CAPECCHI and MITCH SMITH
byline.contributor: Christina Capecchi reported from Minneapolis, and Mitch Smith from Chicago.

lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials and some Somali leaders said the new programs were a way to stop extremism long before an arrest became necessary.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
